Charles Robert Darwin FRS FRGS FLS FZS (; 12 February 1809 – 19 April 1882) was an English naturalist
column4: best known for his contributions to the science of evolution. His proposition that all species of life have descended over time from common ancestors is now widely accepted
column5: and considered a foundational concept in science. In a joint publication with Alfred Russel Wallace
column6: he introduced his scientific theory that this branching pattern of evolution resulted from a process that he called natural selection
column7: in which the struggle for existence has a similar effect to the artificial selection involved in selective breeding. Darwin has been described as one of the most influential figures in human history
column8:
and he was honoured by burial in Westminster Abbey.

Antonie Philips van Leeuwenhoek FRS ( ; Dutch:  (
column3: //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x"" data-file-width=""20"" data-file-height=""20"">listen); 24 October 1632 – 26 August 1723) was a Dutch businessman and scientist in the Golden Age of Dutch science and technology. A largely self-taught man in science
column4: he is commonly known as ""the Father of Microbiology""
column5:
and one of the first microscopists and microbiologists. Van Leeuwenhoek is best known for his pioneering work in microscopy and for his contributions toward the establishment of microbiology as a scientific discipline.

Louis Pasteur ForMemRS (
column3: French: ; 27 December 1822 – 28 September 1895) was a French chemist and microbiologist renowned for his discoveries of the principles of vaccination
column5: and pasteurization. His research in chemistry led to remarkable breakthroughs in the understanding of the causes and preventions of diseases
column6: which laid down the foundations of hygiene
column7: public health and much of modern medicine. His works are credited to saving millions of lives through the developments of vaccines for rabies and anthrax. He is regarded as one of the founders of modern bacteriology and has been honoured as the ""father of bacteriology"" and as the ""father of microbiology"" (together with Robert Koch
column8:
and the latter epithet also attributed to Antonie van Leeuwenhoek).
